Comments_List: A broad overview of statistical mechanics from a unique perspective.

1) better understanding of indistinguishibility/distinguishablility (appearance of quantum mechanics even in "classical" thermo)
2) better understanding of all fundamental thermo
3) better understanding of computational methods in stat mech/biophysics
This course gave me a much more foundational understanding of statistical mechanics. We also covered commonly used simulation techniques and computations.
I developed a good foundation in the theory and applications of statistical mechanics. This knowledge will be beneficial to my research and career.
I learned the mathematics behind monte carlo simulations, and how random fluctuations explain certain phenomena very well

The course was valiant in its effort to cover a huge swathe of material. By the end, I learned the essence of the topics covered and could (but would  need to) look them up and learn more about them to use them if I needed to.

My main issue with the class was that the lectures felt chaotic at times. Victor lectured from memory, which is very impressive, but sometimes it led to errors on the board that meant a derivation ended up confusing more than instructing the class. It was unfortunate that the textbook for the course was more of a novel. That said, Victor had made lecture notes, which were really useful to review outside of class. However, to feel comfortable with the content in the notes took months upon months of engaged reading (hours a day).

Victor was always very friendly and accommodating, and he made himself as available as he could outside of class.

main strength: very interesting, engaging presentation of material, with unexpected insights
main weaknesses: irregular homework assignments and un-transparent grading of exams (not clear why exactly x number of points taken off for a mistake, not x-1 or x+1 etc)
I really enjoyed the assignments that involved coding our own simulations. I think the course could include more organized problem sets.

The strengths of this course were the establishment of the fundamentals of statistical mechanics and numerous examples of how the theory could be applied to meaningful problems. The course could be improved by providing more grading throughout the semester. Since not many grades were received, it was difficult to know how I was performing.

A major strength of this course were the class notes that doubled as a text book of sorts that condensed stat mech into its most important aspects. Everything we learned was important and helped to understand more complex topics. Having additional information be supplementary helped students tailor course to their needs.
I would recommend this course to someone who has already taken stat mech and QM in some form and is comfortable with linear algebra and calculus.
I think it is difficult to recommend to every student, as I felt I needed a more advanced background in quantum chemistry to keep up.
I would recommend this course to any student with an interest in the topic.
Yes, it gives a good understanding of the origin behind macroscale processes in terms of micro scale phenomena. Additionally, must have for simulations people
